Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Kiropraktor vs manuellterapeut: Forskjeller og likheter.

Hva er en kiropraktor?: En kiropraktor er et autorisert helsepersonell med egen grunnutdanning i kiropraktikk. Utdanningen er 5 ar pa universitetsniva og tas ved spesialiserte institusjoner - de fleste norske kiropraktorer har studert ved Syddansk Universitet i Danmark eller ved AECC University College (na Health Sciences University) i England.

Hva er en manuellterapeut?: En manuellterapeut er en fysioterapeut med videreutdanning i manuell terapi. Utdanningsveien er todelt: forst 3 ars bachelorgrad i fysioterapi, deretter 2 ars mastergrad i manuell terapi. Totalt minimum 5 ar, men mange har klinisk erfaring mellom gradene - og den reelle utdanningsveien er ofte 7-8 ar.

Utdanning og autorisasjon: Kiropraktorutdanningen er designet som ett lop. Du soker deg inn med mal om a bli kiropraktor - ikke som pabygg. Studentene fordyper seg i diagnostikk, radiologi og manipulasjonsteknikker gjennom hele studiet. Radiologitrening er integrert: kiropraktorer laerer a lese rontgenbilder og MR-bilder som del av grunnutdanningen. Derfor har kiropraktorer rett til a rekvirere rontgen - en rettighet manuellterapeuter ikke har.

Behandlingsmetoder: En typisk forstekonsultasjon varer 30-45 minutter med grundig undersokelse og ofte behandling samme dag. Oppfolgingstimer er gjerne 15-30 minutter.

Rettigheter i helsevesenet: I Norge har kiropraktorer og manuellterapeuter tilnaermet identiske rettigheter. Begge er primaerkontakter, noe som betyr at du kan oppsoke dem direkte uten henvisning fra fastlege.

Nar velge kiropraktor eller manuellterapeut?: Viktig: Disse punktene beskriver generelle tendenser. Den enkelte behandlers kompetanse og erfaring varierer. En dyktig kiropraktor og en dyktig manuellterapeut vil gi deg et godt resultat for de fleste muskel-skjelettplager.

Hva sier forskningen?: Forskning sammenligner sjelden kiropraktorer og manuellterapeuter direkte.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Finger Numbness.

Three Main Nerves to the Hand: Median nerve: Supplies thumb, index finger, middle finger and half of ring finger
 (palm side)

 Ulnar nerve: Supplies little finger and half of ring finger

 Radial nerve: Supplies the back of the hand and extends the fingers

Neck Causes (Cervical Radiculopathy): When a nerve root in the neck becomes compressed or irritated, it's called cervical radiculopathy. This
 can be caused by disc herniation , foraminal stenosis (narrow nerve canal), or degenerative
 changes.

Hand Causes: The most common cause of finger numbness. The median nerve becomes compressed in the carpal tunnel - a
 narrow passage in the wrist.

Comparison: Neck vs. Hand: Some patients can have both neck problems and carpal tunnel at the same time - this is called "double
 crush syndrome." When a nerve is already compromised at one location, it becomes more vulnerable to
 compression elsewhere.

How is the Diagnosis Made?: A thorough clinical examination can often distinguish between neck and hand causes
Treatment: Treatment depends on the cause of the numbness.

Red Flags - When to See a Doctor?: These symptoms may indicate more serious conditions requiring faster evaluation, such as spinal cord
 compression, stroke, or multiple sclerosis.

Frequently Asked Questions: It depends on which fingers are affected and accompanying symptoms. Thumb, index and middle finger are
 typical for carpal tunnel, while little and ring finger often point to neck or elbow. Neck pain and arm
 radiation indicate neck cause.

"Dizziness is part of aging"

 Research from Imperial College London has established that dizziness is not a normal part of aging.  Pure conservative treatment (footwear + orthotics without injections) succeeds in about

 footwear changes alone are rarely sufficient.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Svimmelhetstypene: Slik skiller du mellom forskjellige former.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen på vertigo og svimmelhet?

 Svimmelhet er paraplybegrepet som dekker alle former for balanseforstyrrelser. Vertigo er en spesifikk type der du opplever at du eller omgivelsene roterer - typisk beskrevet som at "rommet spinner".

 

 
 Hvilken type svimmelhet er vanligst?

 Krystallsyke (BPPV) er vanligst og står for 17-42% av alle svimmelhetstilfeller som utredes. Vestibulær migrene er nest vanligst blant de som har gjentatte anfall.

 

 
 Kan stress forårsake svimmelhet?

 Ja. PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness) er en tilstand der kronisk svimmelhet vedlikeholdes av angst og stress. Det er en reell fysiologisk tilstand, ikke innbilning.

 

 
 Hvordan vet jeg om svimmelheten min er alvorlig?

 Alarmsymptomer inkluderer talevansker, ansiktslammelse, dobbeltsyn, kraftig hodepine eller svelgevansker sammen med svimmelhet. Ring 113 umiddelbart ved slike symptomer.

 

 
 Kan nakken gi svimmelhet?

 Ja, cervikogen svimmelhet fra nakkeproblemer er reelt, men diagnosen er kontroversiell. Nakken inneholder sensorer som sender posisjonsinformasjon til hjernen, og dysfunksjon her kan gi ustøhet.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is vestibular migraine?

 Vestibular migraine is a neurological condition where migraine mechanisms in the brain affect the balance centers. Unlike regular migraine, you do not need to have a headache - only 25% experience headache during dizziness episodes.

 

 
 How common is vestibular migraine?

 Vestibular migraine affects 1-3% of the population and is the most common cause of episodic dizziness. In specialized dizziness clinics, the condition accounts for up to 25% of all newly referred patients.

 

 
 How is vestibular migraine treated?

 Treatment includes preventive medications (propranolol, topiramate), CGRP inhibitors for refractory cases, vestibular rehabilitation, and manual treatment of the neck. Lifestyle changes such as regular sleep and trigger management are also important.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with vestibular migraine?

 Yes, manual treatment of upper cervical vertebrae can provide improvement in many patients. This is due to trigeminocervical convergence - nerve pathways from the upper neck converge with pathways from the vestibular system.

Symptoms

Beskriv symptomer på hekseskudd for Hekseskudd.

Symptomer på hekseskudd

 Symptomene ved hekseskudd er typisk lokalisert til korsryggen og kan variere i intensitet
 Karakteristiske symptomer
 Akutt smerte: Plutselig innsettende, ofte beskrevet som "stikkende" eller "lammende"

 Stivhet: Betydelig redusert bevegelighet i ryggen

 Muskelspenning: Ofte palbar spenning i ryggmuskulaturen

 Smerteførsterking: Bevegelse, hosting, nysing og anstrengelse forverrer smertene

 Lettelse i hvile: Smertene avtar ofte i stillestende stillinger

 Viktig skille: Ukomplisert vs. komplisert

 Ved ukomplisert hekseskudd er smertene begrenset til korsryggen uten utstrålende symptomer til beina. Dersom du opplever utstrålende smerter, nummenhet eller kraftsvikt i beina, kan dette tyde på nerveaffeksjon ( isjias ) og bør vurderes av helsepersonell.

Generer differensialdiagnoser for thorakal smerte hos 35-åring.

Differensialdiagnoser for thorakal smerte, kvinne 35 år:

**Mest sannsynlig (muskuloskeletalt):**
1. Kostovertebral dysfunksjon — ømhet over kostovertebrale ledd, smerte ved dyp inspirasjon
2. Thorakal fasettleddsdysfunksjon — segmental stivhet, lokal ømhet
3. Myofascielt smertesyndrom — trigger points i rhomboideus/trapezius
4. Kostokondritt — ømhet over kostokondrale overganger, Tietzes syndrom hvis hevelse

**Bør vurderes:**
5. Cervikal referred smerte — sjekk nakke-ROM og Spurlings
6. Thoracic outlet syndrom — om armsymptomer foreligger
7. Scheuermanns — om thorakal kyfose er prominent

**Utelukkes (røde flagg):**
8. Kardial årsak — EKG ved belastningsrelatert smerte (lav risiko 35 år kvinne)
9. Lungeemboli — ved brystsmerter + dyspné + risikofaktorer
10. Pneumothorax — akutt onset + dyspné
11. Herpes zoster — ensidig, dermatomalt, vesikulært utslett

Anbefalt fremgangsmåte: Start med grundig muskuloskeletal undersøkelse. Utelukk kardiale og pulmonale årsaker ved atypisk presentasjon.

Describe treatment options for Nociplastic Pain: When the Nervous System Becomes Oversensitive.

Treatment

 

 Treatment of nociplastic pain requires a fundamentally different approach than traditional pain management. The goal is not to "fix" something in the body, but to help the nervous system reduce its oversensitivity.

 Pain Education (Pain Neuroscience Education)

 
 Why Understanding is Important

 
 Understanding why pain occurs reduces fear and catastrophizing

 Knowledge that pain doesn't mean damage provides confidence to move

 Changes how the brain interprets signals from the body

 Studies show that pain education alone can reduce pain and improve function

 
 

 Graded Activity and Exposure

 
 Graded Exercise Training

 Central to treatment
 Controlled increase in physical activity and exposure to feared movements. The goal is to show the nervous system that movement is safe, so the "alarm" gradually decreases.

 
 Start at a level that doesn't provoke significant pain flare-ups

 Increase gradually in small steps

 Focus on function, not pain level

 Accept that some discomfort is normal and not dangerous

 
 

 Psychological Approaches

 
 Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

 Helps identify and change unhelpful thought patterns and behaviors related to pain. Reduces catastrophizing and avoidance behavior.

 

 
 Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT)

 Focuses on accepting pain without fighting it, while living in accordance with personal values. Reduces the amplifying effect of the struggle against pain.

 

 
 Mindfulness

 Attention training can ...

Describe causes and risk factors for Sports Injuries.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Training Errors (Most Common)

 Rapid increases in training volume, intensity, or frequency are responsible for most overuse injuries. The "10% rule" - increasing weekly load by no more than 10% - helps prevent this.

 Biomechanical Factors

 Poor movement patterns, muscle imbalances, weakness, and lack of flexibility can increase injury risk. These are often correctable with targeted exercise.

 Equipment and Environment

 Worn-out footwear, inappropriate equipment, poor playing surfaces, and inadequate protective gear all contribute to injury risk.

 Previous Injury

 A history of previous injury is one of the strongest predictors of future injury. Incomplete rehabilitation and premature return to sport significantly increase re-injury risk.

Beskriv symptomer for Klasehodepine: Den mest intense smerten.

Symptomer

 Hovedsymptomet: Ensidig, ekstrem smerte

 Anfallene varer typisk 15-180 minutter hvis ubehandlet, med et gjennomsnitt på 45-90 minutter (ICHD-3, 2018).

 Autonome tilleggssymptomer

 Under anfall vil du nesten alltid se ett eller flere av disse tegnene på samme side som smerten
 Øyet renner (tøreflod) - forekommer hos 73-91%

 Øyet blir rødt (konjunktival injeksjon) - 60-84%

 Nesen blir tett eller renner - 42%

 Øyelokket henger eller hovner (ptose) - 16-84%

 Pupillen blir liten (miose) 

 Svetting i pannen eller ansiktet 

 Det viktigste kjennetegnet: Uro og agitasjon

 Her skiller klasehodepine seg dramatisk fra migrene . Mens migrenepasientene søker mørke og ro, blir klasehodepinepasienter ekstremt urolige under anfall.

 De vandrer hvileløst rundt, vugger frem og tilbake, holder seg for øyet, eller banker hodet i veggen. Denne agitasjonen ses hos opptil 90% av pasientene.

 Tidsmønster

 Anfallene følger en sløende døgnrytme. Hele 82% av pasientene opplever anfall til nøyaktig samme tid hver dag, ofte mellom kl. 21 og 03. Mange vakner av smertene 1-2 timer etter innsovning.

 Sykdommen har også en sesongrytme - klaseperiodene kommer ofte var og høst, rundt var- og høstjevndøgn.

Symptoms

 Typical Pattern

 Location: Diffuse tenderness along the inside of the shin (lower 1/3)

 Progressive worsening: Despite rest

How is POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnostic Criteria (Heart Rhythm Society 2015)

 To receive a POTS diagnosis, you must meet:

 
 Pulse increase of >=30 beats/min (>=40 for ages 12-19) within 10 minutes of standing

 Or pulse over 120 beats/min when standing

 Absence of orthostatic hypotension (blood pressure drop >=20 mmHg)

 Symptoms have lasted more than 3 months

 No other condition that explains the symptoms

 

 
 Active Standing Test (can be done in clinic)

 A simple test: You lie flat for 5-10 minutes, pulse and blood pressure are measured, you stand up and stay still, and measurements are taken at 1, 3, 5 and 10 minutes. Pulse increase >=30 without blood pressure drop suggests POTS.

 

 
 Red Flags - Seek medical help immediately for:

 
 Chest pain or pressure in the chest

 Severe shortness of breath

 Repeated fainting

 Irregular heartbeat

 Symptoms that worsen rapidly

 Neurological symptoms (vision loss, speech difficulties, one-sided weakness)

 
 POTS itself is not dangerous, but the symptoms can mimic other conditions that require acute treatment.

Describe What is the combination of headache and dizziness? for Headache and Dizziness.

What is the combination of headache and dizziness?

 

 Headache and dizziness are each among the most common complaints people seek healthcare for. When they occur simultaneously, it is rarely coincidental.

 
 
 51%
 of headache patients have dizziness
 

 
 3x
 more often together than by chance
 

 
 8.4 years
 average diagnostic delay
 

 

 
 Why do they occur together?

 Headache and dizziness share many common nerve pathways and structures. Both migraine and the balance organ are closely connected to the brainstem. The neck contains many proprioceptors that communicate with both headache and balance centers in the brain.

Provide a structured clinical overview of De Quervain's Tenosynovitis: Complete Guide.

What is De Quervain's tenosynovitis?: De Quervain's tenosynovitis is a painful condition affecting the tendon sheath on the thumb side of the
 wrist. Two tendons (abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis) pass through a narrow tunnel,
 and when this tunnel becomes tight or irritated, you get symptoms.

Causes and risk factors: Repeated gripping and thumb movements over time - texting, gaming, handwork. Similar mechanisms as in
 mouse arm .

Symptoms and diagnosis: The classic diagnostic test: Place thumb in palm, make a fist around it, and bend wrist toward little
 finger side. If this reproduces the pain, the test is positive.

Treatment: Thumb-offloading splint, activity modification, ergonomic guidance.

Describe Why the Brain "Forgets" to Turn Off the Alarm for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

Why the Brain "Forgets" to Turn Off the Alarm

 

 Imagine a burglar alarm in your house. After an actual break-in (an acute dizziness episode), you adjust the sensitivity to maximum. Suddenly the alarm goes off every time the wind blows. This is how PPPD works.

 After an acute event - such as crystal disease, vestibular neuritis, concussion or a period of intense stress - the brain enters "crisis mode." In PPPD, the brain forgets to turn off this crisis mode.

 Three Things Happen:

 
 Visual Dependence

 The brain no longer trusts the balance system in the ear, so it clings to vision. That's why you become dizzy in the supermarket or when scrolling on your phone. This is also common in vestibular migraine.

 

 
 Body Stiffness

 You unconsciously tense muscles in your neck and legs to "hold on." This causes secondary neck pain and a stiff gait, similar to what is seen in cervicogenic dizziness.

 

 
 Anxiety Loop

 Every time you feel unsteady, the brain thinks "Danger!" and turns up the alarm even more.

 

 
 What Happens in the Brain with PPPD?

 Neuroimaging studies have shown that this is not "imagination" - there are measurable changes in brain function. Reduced activity in the parieto-insular vestibular cortex (PIVC), and increased activity in visual areas. The good news is that the brain is plastic - with proper treatment, these patterns can be reversed.

Provide a structured clinical overview of L4.

Why is L4-L5 so vulnerable?: The L4-L5 segment functions as the workhorse of the lower back. The disc here has the highest disc height in the entire spine - approximately 11 mm - and handles most of the bending and extending movements in the lower back. The combination of high mobility and high load makes this level particularly vulnerable to wear and injury.

Who is affected?: Risk factors include overweight, physically demanding work, diabetes, smoking, and genetic predisposition.

Symptoms of L4-L5 herniation: With the common paracentral herniation type, the L5 nerve root is compressed. This produces a characteristic symptom pattern
Red Flags - When should you see a doctor immediately?: Cauda equina syndrome is a rare but serious condition where the nerve bundle at the bottom of the spinal cord is compressed. It affects approximately 1 in 65,000 people annually, but requires immediate surgical treatment to prevent permanent damage.

Prognosis and Treatment: Meta-analyses show that 66-70% of all lumbar herniations resorb (go back) spontaneously with conservative treatment (Zou et al., Clin Spine Surg, 2024). For sequestered herniations, the resorption rate is even higher - up to 87%. Most experience significant improvement within 3-6 months.

Frequently Asked Questions: Yes, studies show that 66-70% of herniations resorb completely or partially. Larger herniations (extrusion/sequester) actually resorb more often than smaller bulges.

Forklar Morton's Nevrom for en pasient.

Til tross for navnet er Morton's nevrom ikke et ekte nevrom (nervesvulst) . Det er en fortykning og fibrose av den felles plantare digitale nerven mellom tårne - en av mange fot- og ankelplager vi behandler. Tilstanden rammer oftest mellomrommet mellom 3. og 4. ta (66-85% av tilfellene).

 Når nerven utsettes for langvarig trykk og irritasjon, utvikler det seg arrvev rundt nerven (perineural fibrose). Mange beskriver det klassiske symptomet: "som å ha en stein under foten" eller "noe i skoen".

Explain strengthening exercises for Exercises for Stiff Neck.

Strengthening exercises

 Strengthening exercises provide the most lasting effect against stiff neck. A 2024 systematic review confirms that strength training produces significant reduction in pain intensity and disability in office workers with neck problems.

 Chin tuck

 Most important 

 Sit with a straight back and gaze straight ahead

 Pull your chin straight backward — make a "double chin"

 Keep your head level, do not nod down

 Hold 5-10 seconds, release gently

 Dosage: 15-20 repetitions, several times daily

 Why? The chin tuck activates the deep cervical stabilizers (longus colli) that are inhibited in neck pain (Jull 2009). Falla et al. (2007) showed that the chin tuck alone is not sufficient — it must be combined with other exercises. See also the complete neck home program for full progression.

 Isometric resistance

 Forward: Press your forehead against your hand — hold resistance for 5-10 seconds

 Backward: Press the back of your head against your hand

 Sideways: Press your temple against your hand (both sides)

 Dosage: 10 repetitions in each direction

 Tip: The head should not move — this is a pure resistance exercise. Breathe calmly throughout.

 Shoulder blade squeeze

 Sit with arms relaxed at your sides

 Squeeze your shoulder blades together and down

 Hold for 5 seconds, release gently

 Dosage: 15 repetitions

 Effect: Activates the middle and lower trapezius, which counteracts overactive upper trapezius — a key factor in stiffness and tension in office workers.

Forklar Bihulehodepine eller migrene? for en pasient.

Har du hatt gjentatte episoder med hodepine, trykk i ansiktet og tett nese - og antatt at det må være bihulene? Da er du ikke alene. Men ny kunnskap viser at denne antakelsen ofte er feil.

 En stor studie fra 2004 undersøkte nesten 3000 personer som trodde de hadde bihulehodepine. Resultatet var overraskende: 88% oppfylte kriteriene for migrene .

 Feildiagnosen kan være lenge. En studie fra 2013 fant at pasienter i gjennomsnitt hadde vårt feildiagnostisert i nesten 8 år får de fikk riktig diagnose - og over 12% hadde gjennomgått unødvendig bihuleoperasjon.

Describe The Foot's Built-in Support System for Weak Feet: The Root Cause Most People Overlook.

The Foot's Built-in Support System

 

 The arch of the foot is not held up by passive structures alone. It has an active, dynamic support system consisting of four main components:

 
 1. Intrinsic Foot Muscles

 The small muscles inside the foot itself that provide active, dynamic support to the arch. These respond to the surface texture and adapt in real time.

 

 
 2. Plantar Fascia

 The strong connective tissue membrane under the foot that functions as a passive spring - it stores and releases energy with each step.

 

 
 3. Ligaments

 The ligaments that hold the bones together and provide passive stability to the foot's structure.

 

 
 4. Extrinsic Muscles

 The muscles in the lower leg that send tendons down to the foot (like tibialis posterior) and provide powerful, global control.

 

 
 The Key Point

 When the intrinsic muscles are weak, the passive structures (plantar fascia, ligaments) must take over the job. Over time, these become overloaded - and this is how conditions like plantar fasciopathy develop.

Explain Chronic Back Pain to a patient.

Your back aches. Again. You have been in pain for weeks, months, maybe years. Some days are better, other days the pain is there from the moment you wake up until you go to bed. Maybe you have had an MRI that explained nothing. Maybe you have tried treatments that helped for a while, but then the pain came back.

 You are not alone. Chronic back pain is the leading cause of disability worldwide (GBD Study, 2021), and in Norway, musculoskeletal conditions are the leading cause of sick leave (STAMI/NAV, 2024). There is no quick fix, but there are effective strategies. And for most people, there are real opportunities for a better everyday life.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Hodepine Etter Nakkesleng - Whiplash og Hodepine.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hvor lenge varer hodepine etter nakkesleng?

 Hos de fleste (50-80%) går hodepinen over innen 3 måneder. Rundt 20-50% utvikler kroniske plager som varer lengre. Tidlig aktiv behandling reduserer risikoen for kronifisering.

 

 
 Bør jeg bruke nakkekrage?

 Nei, i de fleste tilfeller. Norske helsemyndigheter (Helsenorge.no) anbefaler at krage ikke brukes, eller maksimalt i 48 timer ved grad II-III. Forskning viser at krage kan forlenge symptomene.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor hjelpe med hodepine etter nakkesleng?

 Ja, manuell behandling har moderat evidens for å bedre hodepine og nakkesmerter på kort sikt, spesielt kombinert med Øvelser. Tidlig behandling gir bedre resultater enn å vente.

 

 
 Når bør jeg ta MR av nakken?

 MR er sjelden nødvendig ved ukomplisert nakkesleng. Bildediagnostikk er kun indisert ved nevrologiske utfall eller mistanke om alvorlig skade. Klinisk undersøkelse er ofte mer informativ.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene etter nakkesleng?

 Ja, og du bør stårte tidlig. Helsenorge anbefaler oppstårt innen 4 dager. Begynn med forsiktige bevegelser og Øk gradvis. Unngå kontaktidrett og tunge løft i akuttfasen.

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen på migrene og hodepine fra nakken?

 Cervikogen hodepine starter i nakken og forverres av nakkebelastning. Migrene er ofte pulserende, ensidig og ledsaget av kvalme/lysskyhet. Ved post-traumatisk hodepine ser vi ofte en blanding. Les mer om occipital nevralgi for informasjon om andre typer hodepine som kan oppstå ...

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Vestibularisnevritt.

Hva er vestibularisnevritt?: Tilstanden er den tredje vanligste årsaken til perifer svimmelhet, etter krystallsyke (BPPV) og Menieres sykdom . Den rammer omtrent 3,5-15,5 per 100 000 personer årlig, og forekommer oftest hos voksne mellom 30 og 60 år.

Årsaker og mekanismer: Den eksakte årsaken er ikke fullstendig klarlagt, men flere faktorer er identifisert
Symptomer: Symptomene kommer typisk akutt over noen timer, når maksimal intensitet innen 24 timer, og avtar gradvis over dager til uker.

Diagnostikk: Vestibularisnevritt er primert en klinisk diagnose. Det viktigste er å skille den fra hjerneslag i lillehjernen eller hjernestammen, som kan gi sværtlike symptomer. Omtrent 25% av pasienter med akutt vestibulart syndrom kan ha sentralnervose årsaker.

Behandling: I de første dagene er Målet å lindre symptomer og sikre vaskebalanse. Kvalmestillende og Vestibulære suppressanter kan brukes, men bør kun brukes de første 1-3 dagene. Langvarig bruk "bedover" hjernen og forsinker den naturlige kompensasjonsprosessen.

Prognose: Vestibularisnevritt er en selvbegrensende tilstand med generelt god prognose

Describe What is metatarsalgia? for Metatarsalgia.

What is metatarsalgia?

 

 Metatarsalgia is not a specific diagnosis, but a collective term for pain located in the forefoot - the
 area under the metatarsal heads (ball of the foot). This is where the long midfoot bones (metatarsals)
 meet the toes.

 The pain usually occurs when this area becomes overloaded. Over time, this can lead to soft tissue
 irritation, joint capsule inflammation, or stress reactions in the bone.

 
 
 2nd & 3rd
 metatarsal most often affected
 

 
 Women
 affected more often than men
 

 
 90%+
 improve conservatively

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 Typer frossen skulder

 Primær (idiopatisk)

 Vanligst 

 Oppstår uten kjent årsak. Ingen forutgående skade eller sykdom. De fleste tilfellene er primære.

 Sekundær

 Utvikles som følge av annen tilstand
 Etter skulderskade eller operasjon

 Langvarig immobilisering (armbrudd, slag)

 Rotatormansjettskade

 Etter brystoperasjon

 Skjoldbruskkjertelsykdom: Både hypo- og hypertyreose

 Alder 40-60 år: Sjelden hos yngre

 Kvinner: 70% av tilfellene

 Hjertesykdom: Etter hjerteinfarkt eller hjerteoperasjon

 Parkinsons sykdom 

 Tidligere frossen skulder: 5-34% får det i den andre skulderen (Dias et al., 2005)

 Diabetes og frossen skulder

 Diabetikere har betydelig høyere risiko, og tilstanden kan være mer langvarig og vanskeligere å behandle. God blodsukkerregulering kan bidra til bedre prognose.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety.
Identify red flags for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Red Flags and Differential Diagnoses

 

 Although calcific tendinitis is usually a benign condition, it is important to rule out other causes of
 shoulder pain.

 
 Seek medical attention if you experience:

 
 Fever combined with intense shoulder pain and swelling (may be infection)

 Significant unexplained weight loss

 Previous cancer history with new pain

 Trauma with sudden loss of strength in the arm

 General feeling of illness

 
 Acute calcific tendinitis in the resorptive phase can mimic septic arthritis. When in doubt, seek
 medical attention to rule out infection.

 

 Conditions that may resemble calcific tendinitis

 
 Rotator cuff tendinopathy/tear

 Similar symptom picture, but X-ray will not show calcium. Ultrasound or MRI can distinguish between
 the conditions.

 

 
 Impingement syndrome

 Overlapping symptoms with painful arc. Calcific tendinitis can cause secondary impingement.

 

 
 Frozen shoulder (adhesive capsulitis)

 Also causes significant restriction of movement, but with a different pattern (stiffness in all
 directions).

 

 
 AC joint arthritis

 Pain localized more to the top of the shoulder. X-ray shows changes in the AC joint, not calcium in
 the tendon.

Explain exercises for the first days for Acute Back Pain: What to Do in the First Hours and Days.

Exercises for the First Days

 1. Pelvic Tilts (Lying)

 Lie on your back with bent knees and feet on the floor

 Gently roll your pelvis forward (lower back flattens against the surface)

 Roll your pelvis back (lower back gets a slight curve)

 10 repetitions, 3 times daily

 2. Knee-to-Chest

 Lie on your back with bent knees

 Gently pull one knee toward your chest

 Hold for 20-30 seconds

 Switch sides. Repeat 3 times per side.

 3. Cat-Camel

 Get on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips

 Arch your back up toward the ceiling (cat) - let the head drop

 Sway your back down (camel) - lift the head

 Move gently through a pain-free range, 10 repetitions

 4. Side-Lying Rotation

 Lie on your side with bent knees

 Gently rotate your upper body toward the ceiling

 Hold for 10 seconds

 Switch sides

Describe What Are Minimalist Shoes? for Minimalist Shoes and Barefoot Training: What Does the Research Say?.

What Are Minimalist Shoes?

 

 Minimalist shoes are designed to mimic barefoot walking as much as possible while providing basic protection. They are characterized by several key features:

 
 Characteristics of Minimalist Shoes

 
 Low or zero drop: No height difference between heel and forefoot

 Thin, flexible sole: Typically 3-8mm, allowing the foot to feel the ground

 Wide toe box: Room for toes to spread naturally

 Minimal cushioning: No thick foam layers blocking sensory feedback

 No motion control: No "stabilizing" elements restricting foot movement

 
 

 Popular Brands

 The market for minimalist shoes has grown significantly. Some of the most recognized brands include:

 
 Vivobarefoot: Wide selection for daily use, running and hiking

 Merrell Vapor Glove: Classic for running and training

 Xero Shoes: Affordable entry into minimalist footwear

 Lems: Comfortable everyday shoes with wide fit

 Altra: Zero drop with some more cushioning, popular among ultrarunners

Patient asks: "What is the difference between SLAP lesion and biceps tendinopathy?"

SLAP lesion affects the attachment where the biceps tendon attaches to the labrum, while biceps tendinopathy affects the tendon itself. They can cause similar symptoms and occur together, but SLAP is more associated with overhead sports and instability symptoms.

You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain treatment for Headache in Back of Head.

Treatment

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Chiropractic treatment of headache focuses on the neck and upper back. Treatment may include
 Joint mobilization or manipulation 

 Soft tissue treatment of tight muscles

 Trigger point treatment in suboccipital muscles

 Exercises to improve function

 Evidence for Treatment

 Cervicogenic headache: The evidence is strongest here. A meta-analysis analyzed 20 randomized studies with 1,439 patients. Findings showed moderate to large short-term effect on pain intensity and headache frequency. Effects persisted beyond 3 months, but to a lesser degree.

 Tension headache: The evidence is more nuanced. A meta-analysis found that high-velocity manipulation alone was not effective for tension headache, but soft tissue treatment showed good effect. Trigger point treatment in the suboccipital muscles may be useful for chronic tension headache.

 Realistic Expectations

 Approximately 50-70% of patients with cervicogenic headache experience clinically meaningful improvement. It's important to be aware that relapse is common - several guidelines point out that cervicogenic headache tends to recur.

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Chin tucks: Pull your chin backward as if making a "double chin," hold for 5 seconds, repeat 10 times. Do this 5-7 times daily.

 Deep neck flexor exercises: Lie on your back with slightly bent knees. Make a gentle nodding motion. Hold for 10-15 seconds, repeat 10 times.

 Ergonomic measures: Screen at eye level, arm's length away. Follow the 20-20-20 rule: Every 20 minutes, look at something 20 meters away for 20 seconds.

 Treatment Course

 For cervicogenic headache, research recommends a structured approach: first 4 weeks with 2 times per week focusing on upper neck joint treatment (C1-C3), then weeks 5-8 with 1 time per week and deep neck flexor exercises, followed by maintenance as needed with home exercise programs.

Forklar styrkeøvelser for Øvelser for stiv nakke.

Styrkeøvelser

 Styrkeøvelser gir den mest varige effekten mot stiv nakke. En systematisk oversikt fra 2024 bekrefter at styrketrening gir signifikant reduksjon i smerteintensitet og funksjonshemming hos kontorarbeidere med nakkeplager.

 Chin tuck (hakeinntrekk)

 Viktigst 

 Sitt med rett rygg og blikket rett frem

 Trekk haken rett bakover — lag en «dobbelhake»

 Hold hodet vannrett, ikke nikk ned

 Hold 5-10 sekunder, slipp rolig tilbake

 Dosering: 15-20 repetisjoner, flere ganger daglig

 Hvorfor? Chin tuck aktiverer de dype nakkestabilisatorene (longus colli) som er hemmet ved nakkeplager (Jull 2009). Falla et al. (2007) viste at chin tuck alene ikke er tilstrekkelig — den må kombineres med andre øvelser. Se også komplett nakke-hjemmeprogram for full progresjon.

 Isometrisk motstand

 Fremover: Press pannen mot hånden — hold motstanden i 5-10 sekunder

 Bakover: Press bakhodet mot hånden

 Til siden: Press tinningen mot hånden (begge sider)

 Dosering: 10 repetisjoner i hver retning

 Tips: Hodet skal ikke bevege seg — det er en ren motstandsøvelse. Puster rolig gjennom hele øvelsen.

 Skulderblad-klem

 Sitt med armene avslappet langs siden

 Klem skulderbladene sammen og ned

 Hold 5 sekunder, slipp rolig

 Dosering: 15 repetisjoner

 Effekt: Aktiverer midtre og nedre trapezius, som motvirker overaktiv øvre trapezius — en nøkkelfaktor i stivhet og spenninger hos kontorarbeidere.

Patient asks: "How long does it take for an acute injury to heal?"

Healing time depends on the type and severity of the injury. Mild sprains: 1–3 weeks. Moderate soft tissue injuries: 4–8 weeks. Severe ligament injuries: 3–6 months. Full tissue remodelling can take up to 12 months.

Beskriv symptomer for Skulder Impingement.

Symptomer

 De typiske symptomene ved skulder impingement er godt gjenkjennelige og skiller seg fra andre skuldertilstander
 Smertefull bue (painful arc)

 Det mest karakteristiske symptomet: Smerte som oppstår når du løfter armen ut til siden, typisk mellom 60-120 grader . Under og over dette området er bevegelsen ofte smertefri. Smerten skyldes at strukturene i det subakromiale rommet komprimeres mest i dette området.

 Andre vanlige symptomer

 Nattsmerter: Vondt å ligge på den affiserte skulderen

 Smerte ved overheadbevegelser: Løfte ting over hodet, vaske håret

 Svakhetsfølelse: Vanskelig å holde tunge gjenstander ut fra kroppen

 Stivhet: Gradvis nedsatt bevegelighet ved langvarige plager

 Krepitasjon: Knirking eller klikking ved bevegelse

 Skiller seg fra frossen skulder

 Ved impingement er det primært aktiv bevegelse som er smertefull, mens passiv bevegelighet ofte er bevart. Ved frossen skulder er både aktiv og passiv bevegelighet redusert. Dette er et viktig klinisk skille.

Vurder røde flagg: 75 år mann med akutt forvirring, nakkestivhet, feber 39°C, fotofobi. Ble brakt inn av pårørende. Kjent korsryggsmerte.

HASTEGRAD: AKUTT — Ring 113

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mistanke om meningitt.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Triaden: nakkestivhet + feber + forvirring = meningitt til det motsatte er bevist
- Fotofobi bekrefter meningeal irritasjon

What causes Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation?

Why office work causes shoulder pain

 

 The body was not designed to sit still in the same position for hours. When we do, several things
 happen that strain the shoulders:

 
 Static muscle work

 When you hold your arms in front of you to use the keyboard and mouse, the shoulder muscles
 constantly work to stabilize. Without rest, this leads to fatigue, tension and eventually pain.

 

 
 Forward-leaning posture

 Many lean forward toward the screen. This causes the head to come in front of the shoulders, which
 significantly increases the load on neck and shoulder muscles.

 

 
 Raised shoulders

 Stress, concentration or incorrect desk height causes us to unconsciously raise our shoulders. Over
 time, this leads to chronic tension in the trapezius muscle. This can also affect sleep quality.

 

 
 One-sided strain

 Using the mouse with the same arm all day, the keyboard too far to one side - such asymmetries strain
 one shoulder more than the other. Over time, this can contribute to conditions like biceps tendinopathy or AC
 joint arthritis.

 

 
 
 45%
 of office workers have neck/shoulder problems
 

 
 7+ hours
 average computer time per day
 

 
 20 min
 maximum time in the same position

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Cortisone Injection in Shoulder: Friend or Foe?.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does a cortisone injection in the shoulder last?

 The effect varies significantly. Some experience relief for weeks to months,
 while others have short-lived or no effect. Research shows the effect often wears off after 6-8 weeks,
 and at 3-6 months there's often no difference from placebo.

 

 
 Are cortisone injections dangerous?

 Single injections are generally safe, but repeated injections can weaken tendons
 and cartilage. Studies show increased risk of tendon rupture and worsening of cartilage damage with
 many injections. The recommended maximum is usually 3-4 injections per area per year.

 

 
 When is a cortisone injection in the shoulder the right choice?

 Cortisone can be useful for acute, intense inflammation that prevents
 rehabilitation, as a diagnostic tool, or as a short-term measure when other treatments haven't helped.
 It should not be the first choice for chronic tendon conditions.

 

 
 Can cortisone make shoulder problems worse?

 Yes, in some cases. Cortisone can weaken tendon tissue over time, and some
 experience a "cortisone flare" with temporary increased pain in the first few days after injection. In
 tendinopathy, cortisone can interfere with the natural healing process.

 

 
 What are the alternatives to cortisone injection?

 Alternatives include physiotherapy/chiropractic with exercises, manual therapy,
 shockwave therapy (ESWT), and for some conditions PRP injections. For many shoulder conditi...

What causes Acute Back Pain (Lumbago) - Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

Causes of Acute Back Pain

 

 In most cases (about 90%), acute back pain is what is called non-specific lower back pain. This means
 the pain cannot be attributed to a specific pathological cause that can be detected on imaging.

 Common causes and risk factors:

 
 Muscle and Ligament Strain (most common)

 Sudden movements, heavy lifting, or unusual activities can overload muscles and ligaments in the
 lower back, triggering acute pain and muscle tension.

 

 
 Facet Joint Irritation

 Facet joints are small joints between the vertebrae. Irritation or "locking" of these can cause
 sudden pain, especially with certain movements.

 

 
 Discogenic Pain

 The discs between the vertebrae can be a source of pain, even without a herniation. Pressure on the
 outer layer of the disc (annulus) can cause local lower back pain.

 

 Risk factors:

 
 Sedentary lifestyle or physically demanding work

 Previous episodes of lower back pain

 Poor core muscle strength

 Stress and psychosocial factors

 Smoking increases the risk of back pain

 Overweight

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Kiropraktisk behandling av smerter mellom skulderbladene er vanligvis sammensatt og tilpasses den enkeltes situasjon.

 
 Manipulasjon og mobilisering

 En systematisk gjennomgang og metaanalyse fra Masaracchio og kollegaer (PLOS ONE, 2019) fant at manipulasjon av brystkassen gå signifikant bedre smertelindring enn standard behandling på kort sikt, med gjennomsnittlig forbedring på 13 poeng på en 100-punkts skala. Sammenlignet med placebo var effekten mindre tydelig. Evidensnivået vurderes som moderat.

 Viktig: Tidlig behandling

 Tidlig behandling er assosiert med bedre utfall. Smerte som har vart mer enn tre måneder får behandlingsstart gir betydelig dårligere prognose (Knecht, 2020).

Describe treatment options for Hip Osteoarthritis.

Treatment

 

 Exercise is the Most Important Treatment

 Research shows that exercise is as effective as pain medication for hip osteoarthritis -
 but without side effects. The GLA:D program has shown that 88% avoid surgery with proper exercise
 treatment.

 Strength training - hip and thigh muscles

 Flexibility exercises - maintain mobility

 Low-impact cardio - cycling, swimming, walking

 Balance training - fall prevention

 
 

 Chiropractic Treatment

 
 Manual therapy - joint mobilization

 Soft tissue treatment - tight muscles around the hip

 Exercise prescription - individually tailored program

 Advice - activity modification, weight management

 
 Other treatments

 
 Weight loss - every kg less reduces joint load

 Pain medication - as needed (NSAIDs)

 Cortisone injection - temporary relief

 Hip replacement - when conservative treatment fails

2. Vestibular Migraine (6-29% of dizziness patients)

 The second most common cause of recurrent dizziness, and severely underdiagnosed. Only 10% of those meeting diagnostic criteria are told that migraine causes their symptoms. The condition affects 0.98-2.7% of the general population.

 
 Dizziness episodes lasting minutes to days

 Headache, light/sound sensitivity, or visual disturbances in at least half of attacks

 Previous or current migraine history

 Migraine patients have three times higher risk of developing BPPV

 
 Important: When repositioning maneuvers don't work after three attempts, vestibular migraine should be strongly suspected.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Dizziness.

The Body's Balance System: To understand dizziness, you must first look at our amazing balance system. Balance is not one single thing, but a continuous collaboration between three critical systems that constantly communicate with the brain.

Common Causes of Dizziness: BPPV is the most common cause of dizziness and accounts for 17-42% of all cases. The condition occurs when small calcium crystals dislodge from their normal place in the inner ear and end up in the semicircular canals.

Diagnosis - What Can You Expect?: A thorough examination always starts with listening to your history. I map when symptoms occur, what triggers them, how long they last, and if there are other accompanying symptoms.

Treatment Options: Repositioning maneuvers (Epley/Semont) have an 80-90% success rate . Many experience significant improvement after 1-3 treatments.

Frequently Asked Questions: BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo) is the most common cause and accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness cases. It has a success rate of 80-90% with the Epley maneuver.

Ready to Get Help?: . I offer thorough assessment with VNG and TRV chair to find the cause and provide the right treatment.

What Can Be Done?

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment of stiff thoracic spine focuses on restoring normal mobility through a combination of manual
 techniques and exercises. A systematic review in BMJ Open Sport & Exercise Medicine (Spencer et al., 2020)
 identified 38 different thoracic exercises used in sports settings, but noted that randomized controlled
 studies specifically for athletes are lacking.

 The available research shows moderate effect of mobilization and manipulation for
 improving thoracic rotation and flexibility. For rib problems,
 treatment may also include the costovertebral joints. One study found that thoracic rotation increased
 from 50 to 55 degrees after treatment - while lumbar rotation was reduced, suggesting better distribution
 of load.

 
 In Clinical Practice I Often Combine:

 
 Joint mobilization and manipulation of stiff segments in the thoracic spine

 Soft tissue treatment of shortened muscles (chest muscles, upper trapezius)

 Specific exercises to maintain and improve mobility

 Review of technique and posture in daily life

 
 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Based on the Le Solliec study and other research, the following exercises can help:

 
 
 Thoracic Extension Over Foam Roller

 Lie with the roller across your upper back and gently extend backward. Hold for 30 seconds, repeat at
 three different heights.

 

 
 Thread the Needle

Medisinsk behandling

 Medikamentell behandling er førstevalg ved trigeminusnevralgi.

 Karbamazepin (Tegretol) - gullstandarden

 NNT 1,7-1,8 for minst 50% smertelindring - et av de beste tallene i smertemedisin (WHO EML 2024; PMC MA 2024)

 70-80% oppnår lindring med karbamazepin (NHI.no; Legemiddelhåndboka)

 Blokkerer natriumkanaler i nerven og demper den feilaktige fyringen

 Krever regelmessig blodprøvekontroll (lever, blodverdier)

 Dosejustering er vanlig - effekten kan avta over tid og kreve økning

 Okskarbazepin (Trileptal)

 Alternativ til karbamazepin med potensielt bedre bivirkningsprofil og færre legemiddelinteraksjoner. Brukes ofte når karbamazepin gir for mye bivirkninger.

 Andrevalg og tilleggsbehandling

 Lamotrigin: Som tillegg eller monoterapi

 Baklofen: Som tilleggsbehandling

Clinical summary of Flat Back.

Brief Summary

 What it is: A condition where the thoracic spine lacks its natural backward curve
 (less than 20 degrees kyphosis).

 Who is affected: Young adults (95% under 40 years), gymnasts, ballet dancers, and
 people after certain spinal surgeries.

 Chiropractic treatment: Limited research (only case reports), but individual

 evaluation first.

 Consultation: 45 min first visit, 30 min follow-up

 injury is one of the most dramatic forms of knee pain , especially

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for GTPS - Smerter på Utsiden av Hoften.

Behandling

 

 Førstelinjebehandling: Trening

 Den viktigste studien på GTPS-behandling er LEAP-studien (Mellor et al., BMJ 2018), som sammenlignet trening, kortison og "vent og se".

 
 Resultater etter 1 Ør (LEAP-studien)

 
 Trening: 79% rapporterte global bedring

 Kortison: 58% rapporterte global bedring

 Vent og se: 52% rapporterte global bedring

 
 Trening var klart godt egnet - og effekten varte!

 

 Treningsprinsipper

 
 Isometriske Øvelser først - holder stillingen uten bevegelse

 Gradvis progresjon - fra isometrisk til isotonisk til funksjonell

 Fokus på gluteus medius og minimus

 Unngå kompresjonsstillinger under trening

 Tren 3-4 ganger i uken over minst 12 uker

 

 Kiropraktisk behandling

 Jeg kombinerer ofte:

 
 Bektvevsbehandling av glutealmuskulatur og ITB

 Manuell terapi av hofte og bekken

 Individuelt tilpasset treningsprogram

 Radgivning om belastningsstyring

 

 Hva med kortison?

 Kortison gir rask smertelindring de første ukene, men LEAP-studien viste at effekten ikke varer. Etter 1 Ør var kortisongruppen ikke bedre enn "vent og se"-gruppen. I tillegg kan gjentatte injeksjoner skade senevevet.

 
 Når vurdere kortison?

 Kortison kan vare aktuelt som et "pustehull" for å komme i gang med trening hvis smertene er så sterke at trening ikke lar seg gjennomfore. Men det bør aldri vare en sentral behandlingsform.

Patient asks: "Why do I have headache even though the muscles are the problem?"

Describe What Does the Chiropractor Do? for Pain in Arm, Elbow and Hand.

What Does the Chiropractor Do?

 

 As a chiropractor, I examine why the pain occurs. Is it stiffness in the neck affecting
 the nervous system? Is it trigger points in the shoulder giving referred pain to the wrist? Is it
 repetitive movements overloading the tendons?

 
 
 1

 
 Joint mobilisation and adjustment

 Of stiff joints in neck, shoulder, elbow and wrist

 

 

 
 2

 
 Soft tissue treatment

 Of tight musculature and trigger points

 

 

 
 3

 
 Therapeutic exercises

 Eccentric training for tendinopathies, strength exercises for muscular problems

 

 

 
 4

 
 Ergonomic advice

 Adjustments to how you work or train

 

 

 
 5

 
 Dry needling

 When trigger points are part of the picture

 

 

 
 6

 
 Shockwave/Graston

 As supplement for chronic tendon problems

 

 

 

 Typical treatment course

 
 
 < 6 weeks

 
 Acute problems

 4-6 treatments over 3-4 weeks

 

 

 
 6-12 weeks

 
 Subacute problems

 6-10 treatments over 6-8 weeks

 

 

 
 > 12 weeks

 
 Chronic problems

 8-12 treatments with focus on exercises and prevention

You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain conservative treatment with a chiropractor for Lumbar Foraminal Stenosis.

Conservative Treatment with a Chiropractor

 Conservative treatment is the first choice for foraminal stenosis. All guidelines recommend trying conservative treatment for 3-6 months before considering surgery (AFP, 2024).

 Key Principle: Open the Foramen

 With foraminal stenosis, the treatment logic is opposite to what many are used to. While we often work with extension (backward bending) for common back pain, foraminal stenosis is about flexion - because forward bending opens the nerve canal.

 Manual Treatment

 Lumbar flexion mobilization (side-lying or supine)

 Lateral flexion away from the painful side

 Neural mobilization (gentle nerve gliding techniques)

 Soft tissue treatment for secondary muscle tension

 We avoid sustained extension and rotation toward the painful side

 Exercises (Flexion Program)

 Phase 1 (Weeks 1-4) - Symptom Management

 Double knee-to-chest in supine

 Posterior pelvic tilt

 Seated forward bend ("prayer position")

 Walking program (forward-leaning posture is natural and fine)

 Stationary cycling (seated in flexion)

 Phase 2 (Weeks 4-8) - Gradual Progression

 Bridge exercises with progression

 Core stability with flexion focus

 Hip strength (abductors, gluteus)

 Pool-based exercise

 Longer walks

 Phase 3 (Weeks 8-12+) - Functional Rehabilitation

 General strengthening program

 Functional activities with good body mechanics

 Maintenance program

 Strategies for managing flare-ups

 An important 2024 study showed that the severity of stenosis on MRI does not affect how well the patient responds to exercise (PMC, 2024). This means that even with moderate to severe stenosis, exercise-based rehabilitation can be effective.

Explain Scapular Pain and Cervical Radiculopathy to a patient.

You have pain between your shoulder blades. Perhaps a deep, aching pain that does not respond to massage. Most people think muscle knots and poor posture. But surprisingly often, the cause is higher up - in the neck .

 Research shows that between 37 and 52 percent of patients with cervical radiculopathy (nerve root compression in the neck) experience pain between the shoulder blades. Even more striking: the scapular pain can appear before the arm symptoms - sometimes weeks in advance.

Describe symptoms and causes for Jaw Joint Problems.

Symptoms and Causes

 How does it feel?

 Jaw pain: Deep, aching pain in front of the ear or along the jawline. Worse with
 chewing, yawning or long talking.

 Headache: Affects over half with TMD. Often as pressure behind the eye or a band
 around the temple.

 Ear symptoms: Ear pain, tinnitus or "blocked ear" – without the ear doctor finding
 anything.

 Limited opening: Normal is 40-55 mm (about three fingers vertically).

 Neck pain: Up to 70% of TMD patients have concurrent neck problems.

 Morning stiffness: Common if you clench your teeth at night.

 What causes it?

 Stress and muscle tension

 Go to full article on stress and jaw pain
 ? 

 Most common factor. Under stress, many clench their teeth unconsciously – day and night.

 Poor posture

 Go to full article on text neck and jaw
 ? 

 Forward-leaning head during screen work pulls the jaw backwards and compresses the joint. 76%
 of TMD patients have forward head posture (PMC 2021).

 Teeth grinding (bruxism)

 Go to full article on teeth
 grinding ? 

 8-10% have night-time bruxism (Zielinski 2024). But the connection with TMD pain is more complicated
 than previously thought.

 Neck problems

 Go to full article on neck-jaw
 connection ? 

 Nerve connections between jaw and upper neck (trigeminocervical nucleus) mean that problems in one
 place can cause symptoms in the other.

Describe treatment options for Flat Back (Hypokyphosis).

Treatment

 

 
 IMPORTANT WARNING

 Treatment of hypokyphosis is NOT the same as treatment of common back pain or rounded back.

 Traditional back exercises that focus on "straightening" the back through extension are
 counterproductive and potentially harmful for a person who already has a back that is too
 straight.

 

 What can the chiropractor do?

 Research on treatment of hypokyphosis is very limited - there are no randomized controlled trials.
 Available evidence comes from case reports and small patient series.

 
 Promising results from case reports

 
 A 33-year-old man with Straight Back Syndrome achieved 10 degrees improvement over 36 treatments
 (PMC, 2017)

 A series of 10 patients showed an average 11.3 degrees improvement over 25 treatments (Oakley et
 al., 2018)

 
 Evidence level: Very low. Only
 case reports exist, and independent replication is lacking.

 

 Treatment course

 Based on available case reports, treatment requires significant effort: 3-4 times per week over 9-16
 weeks, totaling 25-36 treatments. This is far more intensive than standard back treatment.

Explain basic exercises (start here) for Strengthening Exercises for Lower Back: Build a Stronger Back.

Basic Exercises (Start Here)

 1. Dead Bug

 Target: Deep core stability

 Lie on your back with arms up and legs at 90 degrees

 Press lower back flat against the floor

 Slowly lower opposite arm and leg toward the floor

 Keep lower back stable the entire time

 Return to start, switch sides

 10-15 repetitions each side

 2. Bird-Dog

 Target: Back extensors and stability

 Get on all fours, neutral spine

 Extend opposite arm and leg horizontally

 Hold for 3-5 seconds

 Switch sides without swaying in the back

 10-12 repetitions each side

 3. Glute Bridge

 Target: Glutes and hip extensors

 Lie on your back with bent knees, feet on the floor

 Squeeze glutes and lift hips

 Create a straight line from shoulders to knees

 Hold for 2-3 seconds

 Lower down with control

 15-20 repetitions

 4. Plank

 Target: Total core stability

 Support on forearms and toes

 Body straight like a plank

 Tighten abs and glutes

 Hold as long as you can with good technique

 Goal: 30-60 seconds

 5. Side Plank

 Target: Obliques and side stability

 Lie on your side, support on forearm

 Lift hips up from the floor

 Keep body in a straight line

 Hold 20-30 seconds

 Switch sides

Treatment

 

 Pharmacological Treatment (First-Line)

 
 Current Medications

 
 Carbamazepine: Most commonly used, start 100-200 mg x2, titrate up

 Oxcarbazepine: Often better tolerated than carbamazepine

 Gabapentin: Alternative if intolerant

 Pregabalin: Alternative

 Baclofen: Can be used as add-on

 
 

 For Cardiac Involvement

 
 Cardiac Monitoring

 
 Continuous ECG monitoring

 Temporary pacemaker may be necessary

 Atropine for acute bradycardia episodes

 
 

 Surgical Treatment

 Surgical Options

 
 Microvascular decompression (MVD): For proven vascular compression - high success rate (85-95%)

 Percutaneous rhizotomy: Destruction of nerve root

 Stereotactic radiosurgery: Gamma knife

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Tommelartrose (CMC-1): Komplett guide.

Behandling

 

 
 Konservativ behandling er førstevalg

 
 De fleste får god lindring uten kirurgi

 Handtrening og styrking av stabiliserende muskler

 Tommelortose for avlastning

 Aktivitetsmodifikasjon

 
 

 Behandlingsplan

 
 1. Ortose

 Tommelortose stabiliserer leddet og reduserer belastning. Kan brukes ved behov eller kontinuerlig.

 

 
 2. Handtrening

 StyrkeØvelser for tommelens stabiliserende muskler. Øker stabilitet og reduserer smerter.

 

 
 3. Aktivitetsmodifikasjon

 Ergonomiske hjelpemidler, endring av grepsteknikk, og pausestrategier.

 

 
 4. Manuell behandling

 Bløtvevsbehandling av overbelastet muskulatur, forsiktig mobilisering. Behandling av triggerpunkter i tommelmuskulaturen kan også våre nyttig.

 

 
 Kortison ved tommelartrose

 I motsetning til noen andre tilstander har kortison begrenset effekt ved tommelartrose. Effekten er ofte kortvarig (2-3 uker), og gjentatte injeksjoner anbefales ikke. Handtrening gir bedre langtidsresultater.

Red flags for Temporal Arteritis?

Call emergency services for sudden vision loss

 Temporal arteritis is a medical emergency. Sudden vision loss, double vision, or new-onset severe headache in people over 50 years of age requires immediate medical evaluation. Vision loss caused by temporal arteritis is usually permanent. Every hour without treatment increases the risk of lasting blindness.

 Contact emergency services immediately - treatment with corticosteroids should be started THE SAME DAY the suspicion arises, without waiting for confirmatory tests.

 Severe pain after a fall or accident, especially if you can't lift your arm

 Pain lasting over 2-3 weeks without improvement

 Gradual worsening of symptoms

Describe types and causes for ICR Syndrome.

Types and Causes

 Pain from the carotid region can have several causes, from benign to life-threatening
 Carotid Dissection

 SERIOUS 

 A tear in the artery wall that leads to blood accumulation (hematoma) in the wall. This narrows the artery and can lead to stroke.

 Can occur spontaneously or after neck trauma/manipulation

 Often causes one-sided neck/headache with Horner's syndrome

 High risk of ischemic stroke

 Requires urgent evaluation and treatment 

 Transient Perivascular Inflammation of the Carotid artery (TIPIC)

 Previously called "idiopathic carotidynia". A transient inflammatory condition in the tissue around the carotid artery.

 One-sided neck pain over the carotid

 Tenderness on palpation

 Imaging shows thickening of tissue around the artery

 Good prognosis - often resolves on its own

 Temporal Arteritis (Giant Cell Arteritis)

 SERIOUS 

 Inflammation in large and medium-sized arteries, most common in people over 50.

 Headache, often in the temples

 Jaw claudication (pain when chewing)

 Vision disturbances - risk of blindness

 Requires urgent treatment with steroids 

 Carotid Aneurysm

 Bulging of the artery wall that can compress nerves or cause pain.

 Often asymptomatic until it becomes large

 Can cause pulsating mass in the neck

 Risk of rupture or embolization

 Atherosclerosis and Carotid Stenosis

 Fat deposits in the artery wall leading to narrowing.

 Often asymptomatic

 Can cause transient vision loss (amaurosis fugax)

 Risk of stroke with severe stenosis

Explain how can chiropractic help? for Shoulder Pain.

How Can Chiropractic Help?

 At TheBackROM I combine manual treatment with active rehabilitation. Research shows that this combination gives the good results for most shoulder problems.

 Manual Treatment

 I use various techniques to improve joint and muscle function
 Joint mobilization for better mobility

 Soft tissue techniques for tense muscles and trigger points

 Treatment of neck and thoracic spine - many shoulder problems are connected to stiffness here

 Active Rehabilitation

 Exercises are the cornerstone of effective shoulder treatment. Research shows that structured exercise programs are as effective as surgery for many conditions (Kukkonen et al., 2014). You'll receive
 Specific strengthening exercises tailored to your diagnosis

 Stretches and mobilization exercises

 Home exercises you can do between treatments

 Guidance on ergonomics and activity modification

 What Can You Expect?

 First Consultation 

 I always start with a thorough examination
 Discussion about your symptoms and how they affect your daily life

 Physical examination of shoulder, neck and back

 Testing of strength and movement

 Clear diagnosis and treatment plan

 Typical Treatment Times

 Mild problems: 4-6 weeks

 Moderate problems: 6-12 weeks

 Frozen shoulder: 12-24 months (but improvement comes gradually along the way)

 Chronic problems: May require longer follow-up

 You'll see gradual improvement, not sudden cure. Most need 8-12 treatments spread over the treatment period, combined with daily home exercises.

Findings:

Facettleddene er små ledd som forbinder ryggvirvlene på hver side av ryggsøylen. Når disse leddene blir irriterte, betente eller degenererte, oppstår facettleddssyndrom - en vanlig årsak til ryggsmerte.

 Den gode nyheten: De fleste med facettleddssyndrom får betydelig bedring med konservativ behandling. Mange merker forbedring etter 2-4 uker med regelmessig behandling og øvelser.

INITIAL KONSULTASJON

Pasient: [Navn], [alder] år
Dato: [Dato]
Konsultasjonstype: Ny pasient

---
SUBJEKTIV:

Hovedklage:
Pasienten oppsøker klinikken grunnet korsryggsmerter med utstråling til venstre ben.

Symptomstart og forløp:
Smertene startet for 2 uker siden etter løfting på jobb. Gradvis forverring første uken, nå stabil. Utstrålingen til benet kom 4-5 dager etter ryggsmertene.

Lokalisasjon og utstråling:
Smerte i nedre lumbalområde sentralt til venstre, med utstråling til venstre sete, baksiden av låret og ned til leggen.

Smertekvalitet:
Verkende, stiv smerte i ryggen. Brennende, stikkende smerte i benet. VAS rygg 5/10, VAS ben 6/10.

Forverrende faktorer:
Sitting >20 min, fremoverluting, hoste/nysing, bilkjøring.

Lindrende faktorer:
Gange korte strekninger, ligge på siden med pute mellom knærne, stå.

Tidligere episoder:
To tidligere episoder med ryggsmerte (2020, 2023), begge uten bensmerter, begge behandlet med god effekt.

Generell helse:
Generelt frisk. Ingen kjente sykdommer. Ingen faste medisiner. Ingen allergier.

Røde flagg screening:
Benekter sadel-anestesi, blære/tarmproblemer, feber, vekttap, nattlige smerter som vekker, tidligere kreft.

Sosiale forhold:
Arbeider som elektriker. Gift, to barn. Bor i enebolig. Røyker ikke. Moderat fysisk aktiv.

---
OBJEKTIV:

Observasjon:
Velbefinnende. Antalgisk holdning med lett fleksjon og sideskift mot høyre. Flatet lumballordose. Forsiktig gangmønster.

Aktiv ROM lumbal:
- Fleksjon: Betydelig redusert, finger-gulv 40cm, provoserer bensmerter
- Ekstensjon: Moderat redusert, 15°
- Lateralfleksjon: Redusert venstre 15°, høyre 25°
- Rotasjon: Lett redusert bilateralt

Palpasjon:
- Paravertebral muskelspasme L4-S1, mest venstre
- Segmental ømhet L4-L5, L5-S1
- Triggerpunkter gluteus medius bilateralt
- IS-ledd: Ua

Ortopediske tester:
- SLR: Positiv venstre 40° med reproduksjon av bensmerter, negativ høyre
- Slump test: Positiv venstre
- Kemps test: Positiv venstre
- Faber: Negativ bilateralt
- Valsalva: Lett provoserende

Nevrologisk undersøkelse:
- Kraft: L2-S1 5/5 bilateralt, L5 dorsalfleksjon 4+/5 venstre
- Reflekser: Patella 2+ bil, Achilles 2+ bil
- Sensibilitet: Lett nedsatt lateralt legg venstre
- Babinski: Negativ bilateralt

---
VURDERING:

Diagnose:
1. Lumbal diskusprolaps med L5 radikulopati, venstre side
   ICPC-2: L86 Ryggsyndrom med utstråling

Klinisk resonnering:
Presentasjonen med lumbal smerte etterfulgt av dermatomal benutstråling, positiv SLR og Slump, kombinert med lett sensorisk og motorisk påvirkning i L5-distribusjonen, er konsistent med lumbal diskusprolaps med radikulopati. Mekanisk forverring ved økt intradiskalt trykk (sitting, Valsalva) støtter diskogen etiologi.

Røde flagg:
Ingen røde flagg identifisert. Cauda equina screening negativ.

Prognose:
Forbeholden. De fleste diskusprolapser responderer på konservativ behandling, men nevrologisk påvirkning krever nøye monitorering.

---
PLAN:

Behandling i dag:
- Leddmobilisering lumbal (forsiktig, unngå fleksjon)
- BVM paraspinalt, piriformis, glutealt
- Nevral mobilisering (slider teknikk)
- McKenzie ekstensjon instruert

Hjemmeøvelser:
- McKenzie ekstensjon (prone press-ups) x10, 5 ganger daglig
- Unngå sitting >20 min
- Gå korte turer hyppig

Oppfølging:
- Ny time om 2-3 dager
- Evaluere respons etter 4-6 behandlinger
- MR lumbal vurderes ved manglende bedring etter 4 uker eller ved nevrologisk forverring

Pasienten informert om:
- Diagnose og forventet forløp
- Varselsymptomer (økende svakhet, blære/tarmproblemer) → kontakt umiddelbart
- Realistiske forventninger til bedring

You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain chiropractic treatment for scoliosis for Scoliosis – Curved Spine in Children and Adults.

Chiropractic Treatment for Scoliosis

 A chiropractor cannot straighten a structural scoliosis. No manual treatment can. A systematic review from 2023 concluded that there is insufficient evidence for spinal manipulation alone as treatment for curve correction in AIS (Sun et al. 2023, BioMed Research International).

 What a chiropractor can contribute, however
 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Pain relief: Mobilization and soft tissue treatment can help relieve pain, particularly in adults with degenerative scoliosis

 Mobilization of stiff segments: Focus on the concave side of the curve to improve range of motion

 Exercise guidance: Tailored program focusing on core muscles and posture

 Monitoring: Tracking the curve in children and adolescents, with X-ray referral as needed

 Collaboration with orthopedic specialist: Referral when the curve approaches 25 degrees or progresses rapidly

 For adult degenerative scoliosis, manual treatment is a useful tool for pain management. Combined with exercises and general activity, it can contribute to better daily function.

 Combination Treatment Shows Promising Results

 A 2024 study found that the combination of specific scoliosis exercises and manual therapy produced better outcomes than exercises alone – for both trunk deformity and quality of life (BMC Musculoskeletal Disorders 2024). It is important to emphasize that this applies to symptom reduction and functional improvement, not curve correction.

What is the prognosis for Whiplash?

Prognosis - What can you expect?

 

 Three typical courses (Sterling et al., Pain, 2010)

 
 Mild course (~45-50%)

 Full recovery within 2-3 months with minimal residual symptoms.

 

 
 Moderate course (~30-40%)

 Partial recovery with persistent mild to moderate symptoms.

 

 
 Severe course (~15-20%)

 Poor recovery with chronic moderate to severe symptoms.

 

 
 The first three months are crucial

 An important finding is that the first three months are decisive for long-term prognosis. A study
 showed that 93% of those who were symptom-free at three months remained symptom-free after two years.
 Conversely, 86% of those with symptoms at three months still had symptoms after two years.

 

 
 
 ~50%
 recover within 3 months
 

 
 53%
 reduced relapse risk with exercise
 

 
 93%
 symptom-free at 3 months stay well
 

 

 Preventing relapse

 Exercise reduces the risk of new episodes by 53% (RR 0.47) according to a
 meta-analysis from 2023 (Campos, JOSPT, 2023). This is the most important preventive factor. Regular
 exercise - especially neck and shoulder stabilizing exercises - is highly recommended.

Explain Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide to a patient.

Vestibular hypofunction means that the balance organ in the inner ear is not functioning properly. The balance organ, also called the vestibular system, normally sends information to the brain about the head's movements and position. This information is crucial for two things: maintaining balance and having stable vision during movement. Dizziness can have many causes, and vestibular hypofunction is one of the most common.

 When this function is weakened or lost, a mismatch occurs between the signals the brain expects and what it actually receives. The result is dizziness, imbalance and visual disturbances - especially when you move.

Assess red flags: 55-year-old female with sudden vision loss in right eye over past 24 hours. Neck pain for the past week. No headache, no temporal tenderness. Normal temporal artery pulsation.

URGENCY: URGENT — Emergency department

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Acute monocular vision loss.

Clinical reasoning:
- Sudden vision loss = ophthalmological/neurological emergency REGARDLESS of cause
- Possible causes: retinal artery occlusion, optic neuritis, GCA (even without typical symptoms)
- Absence of temporal tenderness and headache does NOT exclude GCA — up to 20% have atypical presentation
- Neck pain + vision loss can also indicate carotid dissection with retinal emboli

ACTION: Emergency department/eye emergency IMMEDIATELY. Urgent ESR/CRP (GCA screening). Ophthalmoscopy. CT angiography neck vessels. Do not perform cervical treatment.

Hva forårsaker Karpaltunnelsyndrom: Komplett guide?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Karpaltunnelsyndrom oppstar når trykket i tunnelen blir for høyt. Dette kan skyldes:

 
 Hevelse av senene (vanligst)

 Repetitiv belastning eller overbruk kan føre til hevelse i senerØrene som går gjennom tunnelen, og redusere plassen til nerven.

 

 
 Hormonelle faktorer

 Graviditet, overgangsalder, hypothyreose og diabetes Øker risikoen gjennom væskeopphopning og vevshevelse.

 

 
 Anatomiske faktorer

 Noen har naturlig trangere karpaltunnel. Tidligere handleddsbrudd kan også trange tunnelen.

 

 
 Repetitivt arbeid

 Kontorarbeid, kassaarbeid, produksjonsarbeid - alt med gjentatte handbevegelser over tid. Se også musearm.

 

 Viktige risikofaktorer

 
 Kjénn: Kvinner rammes 3 ganger oftere enn menn

 Graviditet: Vanlig i siste trimester (væskeopphopning)

 Diabetes: Økt risiko for nervesykdom generelt

 Overvekt: BMI over 30 Øker risikoen betydelig

 Leddgikt: Betennelse kan påvirke seneskedene

 Arvelig: Tendens til å gå i familier

Symptomer

 Symptomene utvikler seg typisk gradvis over tid, men kan også oppstå mer akutt etter skade.

 Vanlige symptomer

 Hevelse langs innsiden av ankelen

Research has documented the following changes:

 
 Elevated substance P (pain-transmitting substance) in spinal fluid

 Reduced serotonin, noradrenaline and dopamine

 Weakened natural pain inhibition from the brain

 Altered activity in brain areas that process pain (Gracely et al., 2002)

 
 

 Risk factors (ranked by evidence)

 A systematic review of 37 prospective cohort studies published in PAIN (Creed, 2020):

 
 Sleep disturbances/non-restorative sleep - strongest evidence

 Previous headache and other pain conditions

 Depression

 Illness behavior (excessive worry about symptoms)

 Female sex and middle age (40-60 years)

 
 

 
 
 4
 Symptoms

 experience:

 
 
 Chest symptoms

 
 Pain around the sternum and rib cage

 Tenderness when pressing on the junction between ribs and cartilage

 Pain that worsens with deep breathing or stretching

 Varying location - the pain "moves around"

 Muscle tightness in neck, shoulders and upper back - often pain between the shoulder blades

You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain treatment – bracing, exercises and follow-up for Scoliosis – Curved Spine in Children and Adults.

Treatment – Bracing, Exercises and Follow-up

 Mild Scoliosis (10–25 degrees)

 Most people with mild scoliosis live completely normal lives. Treatment focuses on monitoring and prevention
 X-ray check-ups every 6–12 months during growth

 Specific exercises (Schroth method)

 Chiropractic treatment for pain relief and mobility as needed

 Bracing is usually not necessary

 Moderate Scoliosis (25–40 degrees)

 This is where bracing becomes the first-line treatment, especially for children and adolescents who are still growing.

 The BrAIST Study (Weinstein et al. 2013, NEJM)

 The landmark BrAIST study showed that bracing achieved a 72% success rate compared to 48% with observation alone (Weinstein et al. 2013, NEJM). A clear dose-response was observed: the more hours per day, the better the outcome. 16–23 hours of daily wear is recommended for the best results.

 Schroth Exercises

 Schroth is the best-documented exercise method specifically for scoliosis. A 2023 meta-analysis found an average Cobb angle reduction of 3.18 degrees (95% CI: -4.30 to -2.07), with improved quality of life and reduced trunk rotation (PMC ).

 A 2024 network meta-analysis found that the combination of Schroth and bracing was among the well-documented approaches for slowing progression (Neurosurgery Focus 2024).

Forklar behandling for Horisontal Kanal BPPV.

Behandling

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Behandling av horisontal kanal BPPV krever spesialiserte reposisjonsmanøvrer
 BBQ-roll (Lempert-manøver)

 Pasienten roteres 360 grader i fire steg à 90 grader, med hodet hevet 30 grader. Hver posisjon holdes i 30-60 sekunder. En systematisk oversikt fra 2025 konkluderte med at BBQ-roll er en effektiv behandling. Studier viser 74% bedring etter en behandling og 85% innen tre behandlinger .

 Gufoni-manøver

 En systematisk oversikt fra 2024 med 10 studier og 1025 pasienter viste at Gufoni-manøveren er effektiv. For geotropisk variant ligger suksessraten på 71-92% , mens apogeotropisk variant har lavere respons på 63-78% . Fordelen er at den er lettere å utføre hos eldre pasienter.

 TRV-stol

 For komplekse tilfeller kan TRV-stol (en spesialisert behandlingsstol) benyttes. Denne metoden gir presisjonskontroll over hastighet, vinkel og amplitude.

 Behandlingsforløp - realistiske forventninger

 Best case (ca. 40-50%): Symptomfri etter 1-2 behandlinger. 75% er symptomfrie etter første konsultasjon

 Typisk case (ca. 30-40%): Krever 3-5 behandlinger over 2-3 uker

 Kompliserte tilfeller (ca. 15-20%): Bilateral involvering eller apogeotropisk variant kan kreve 6+ behandlinger

What causes Headache and Dizziness?

Causes - from most to least common

 

 
 1. Vestibular Migraine

 Vestibular migraine is the most common cause of episodic dizziness in adults, affecting 0.9-2.7% of the population. Among migraine patients, 10.3% have vestibular migraine.

 What is unusual about this condition is that headache and dizziness often do not occur simultaneously. On average, 8 years pass from the first migraine until vestibular symptoms develop.

 
 Dizziness episodes lasting from minutes to hours

 Light and sound sensitivity during attacks

 Worsening with head movements

 Often motion sickness throughout life

 Women are affected 3-5 times more often than men

 
 Note: Vestibular migraine is highly underdiagnosed. Only 10-20% of patients receive the correct diagnosis.

 

 
 2. Cervicogenic Dizziness (neck-related)

 Dizziness caused by neck problems affects 40% of patients with neck pain. Of these, 59.7% were related to myofascial pain syndrome (muscle tension with trigger points). This often overlaps with cervicogenic headache.

 The neck contains extremely many proprioceptors (position sensors) - especially in the small muscles at the top toward the skull. When these send incorrect signals, a conflict arises between what the neck "tells" the brain and what the balance organ in the ear registers.

 
 Dizziness with head movements

 Neck pain or stiffness

 Often triggered by positions or activities

 SCM trigger points can cause both headache and dizziness

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Tennisskader.

Biomekanikken i tennis: For å forstå tennisskader må vi forstå bevegelsene. Tennis krever mye av kroppen - raske retningsskift, repeterte overheadbevegelser og rotasjonskrefter gjennom hele den kinetiske kjeden fra fot til håndledd. Et problem i ett ledd forplanter seg videre og kan føre til overbelastning andre steder.

De vanligste tennisskadene: Tennisskader spenner fra kroniske overbelastningsskader til akutte forstuinger. Her er de vanligste, organisert etter kroppsdel og hyppighet
Tennisalbue - behandling med sterk evidens: Tennisalbue fortjener ekstra oppmerksomhet fordi den er så utbredt blant tennisspillere - og fordi behandlingen har overraskende sterk evidens.

Forebygging av tennisskader: De fleste tennisskader kan forebygges. Her er hva forskningen sier om de viktigste tiltakene
Røde flagg - når bør du stoppe og søke hjelp?: De fleste tennisskader er overbelastningsskader som responderer godt på tilpasset trening og behandling. Men noen symptomer krever rask vurdering
Kiropraktisk behandling av tennisskader: Som kiropraktor ser vi hele den kinetiske kjeden - fra håndledd til hofte. Et problem i albuen kan ha rot i skulderen. En skulderplage kan henge sammen med stiv brystrygg. Denne helhetlige tilnærmingen er avgjørende for å finne den faktiske årsaken til skaden.

Trenger du hjelp med en tennisskade?: . Jeg undersøker hele den kinetiske kjeden, diagnostiserer og lager en plan for rehabilitering og forebygging - slik at du kommer raskest mulig tilbake på banen med lavest mulig risiko for tilbakefall.

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Kalkskulder: Alt du trenger å vite.

Symptomer

 

 Symptomene ved kalkskulder varierer betydelig avhengig av hvilken fase tilstanden er i:

 Typiske symptomer

 
 Smerte: Lokalisert til utsiden av skulderen/overarmen. Kan stråle ned til albuen.

 Nattesmerte: Vanlig, særlig når man ligger på affisert side. Les mer om søvn og skuldersmerter

 Bevegelsesinnskrenkning: Vansker med å løfte armen til siden og over hodet

 Plutselig forverring: Akutt, intens smerte ved overgang til resorpsjonsfasen

 

 
 Akutt presentasjon (resorpsjonsfasen)

 Plutselig debut av intense smerter, ofte om natten. Skulderen kan våre svært om til å berore, og pasienten holder ofte armen helt stille for å unngå smerte. Tilstanden kan ligne på septisk artritt eller gikt.

 

 
 Kronisk presentasjon (hvile-/dannelsesfasen)

 Gradvis Økende smerte over tid. Smerten forverres ved aktivitet, særlig bevegelser over skulderhøyde. Kan ligne på impingement-syndrom.

 

 
 Kliniske tester

 Ved undersøkelse finner man ofte:

 
 Smertefull bue ved abduksjon (60-120 grader)

 Positiv Neer's og/eller Hawkins test

 Punktomhet over supraspinatus-feseet

 I akutt fase: Varme, hovelse, uttalt omhet

Describe causes and risk factors for Spinal Stenosis.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Spinal stenosis is almost always caused by age-related changes in the spine. Over 95% of cases are
 degenerative stenosis.

 Facet Joint Osteoarthritis

 Wear in the small joints at the back of the spine leading to thickening and bone spurs.

 Thickening of Ligamentum Flavum

 The yellow ligament located behind the spinal canal can become thicker with age and take up space
 from the nerves.

 Disc Degeneration

 The discs between the vertebrae lose height and can bulge into the canal. This can also lead to herniation .

 Osteophytes

 Bone spurs that grow into the spinal canal or nerve exits.

 Risk Factors with Documented Association

 Age over 60: 3-5 times higher prevalence

 Obesity: BMI over 30 gives more than double the risk

 Diabetes: Found in 29% of stenosis patients vs 10% in the general population

 Spondylolisthesis : Vertebral slippage can
 contribute to stenosis
